utterances: There isn't a person in our family that's got the guts to eat raison toast.
One night for dinner I fixed something so bad the cat covered it.
Now the irony is on this DVD, in this documentary, we see you reveling in your kitchen.
You're a great cook, as it turns out.
Oh but my dear Lynn, I swear, when I hear my own material, I still smile and I still have to laugh.
But you are a great cook, aren't you?
I've got to get that in.
I just - I had a call - excuse me - from Elliott Gould.
He's one of my friends with whom I play gin, and I always cook dinner for him.
And I always allow him to order what he'd like to eat because I do love to cook and I am a good cook.
I'm not a gourmet cook, but I'm a good cook.
And I said - he had ordered lamb chops.
And then he thought about it, and he said no, I want your meatloaf.
I make the world's greatest meatloaf.
See, now, that's not gourmet; it's just good food.
I just want to remind our listeners, if you have any questions for Phyllis Diller, the number is 800-989-8255.
And we are going to go to Lindy(ph), and Lindy is calling from North Carolina, I believe.

Phyllis, I have heard that you are a good cook, but I always want to say that I saw you - I think I was in first grade because you came out to dinner at my mom and dad's house, Bill(ph) and Cora(ph) in Summit, New Jersey.
And I thought you were the most beautiful woman I had ever seen and the most fascinating.
And it's fun to think of how much fun - you have gained popularity from making fun of your looks when I thought you were so beautiful.
I don't know if you remember going out to Summit, New Jersey, and Bill and Cora.
Why didn't you tell me you're a Marinas.
I had such a crush on your father, Bill Marinas.
Oh of course I remember all of that.
I was served a wonderful turkey dinner
(Unintelligible) I sat beside you, and then you gave us lovely photographs, and you signed them, and I took them to school so proud.
And you were one of the little kids.
I am one of the little kids.
Your father was such a brilliant man.
He was - I had a mad, wild crush on him in high school, and then he ran off with Cora.
Well, nice to hear your voice.
We hear testimony of how beautiful you were, and yet you didn't play that up at all in your comedy.
You know, something that I was thinking as I was listening to your act is - and it's very different from the comedy today, I think - those one-liners that you shot out.
That was a real mark of what the stand-up comic did at that time, I think.
And you can't just say at that time because this Rodney Dangerfield was the same type of operator.
In other words, it's the only way in the world to get as many laughs as you can out of an audience, because you don't have long set-ups, and you don't do, like, sitcom.
But you've got to come up with a lot of them to get through a show.
Someone clocked me one night at 800 one-liners.
Well, that means you've got a good memory and you've got to hook them all together so it sounds like an act.
It mustn't sound like you're reading them out of a book.
You have to make it - it has to sound like a story.
And we're going to go to Bryant(ph), and he's in Ypsilanti, Michigan.
Hey, Phyllis, in 1994, I bought a bar from a guy named John Ferris(ph) in Ypsilanti, Michigan, and he said you used to come in and crack the patrons up with your jokes.
I was a young housewife with only two children at that time and already drinking.
